content.title: Descriptive Paper Rubric
content.instructionsInteractive: Click on the plus sign in each cell to display the rubric text. Use the directional arrows to navigate through the rubric.
content.instructionsStatic: Use this 6-point rubric to plan and score a descriptive paper.

tr.td: The topic is clear and interesting with memorable details about all five senses.
The topic is interesting. The writer uses all five senses.
The topic is interesting. The writer uses two or three of the five senses.
The topic could be more interesting. The writer uses one or two of the five senses.
The topic is confusing. Sensory details are sketchy.
The topic is not clear. Sensory information is missing.
The writer uses the five senses to organize the details. The writing is organized well.
Most of the details follow the five senses. The writing makes sense.
The writing generally makes sense. Details are not always organized with the senses.
Many of the details are out of order or unrelated to the topic.
The organization is confusing and does not help the reader understand the topic.
The writing is not organized and is a collection of random thoughts.
The writer uses a personal “you” voice. The voice clearly belongs to this writer.
The writer generally uses a personal “you” voice and speaks to the reader.
The writer speaks to the reader some of the time.
The writer’s voice speaks to the reader and then fades.
The writer does not speak directly to the reader. The writer’s voice is faint.
The writing lacks voice.
Describing words and sensory information paint a clear picture.
Describing words help the reader use the five senses to picture the topic.
Most of the words help the reader use the five senses. The image is clear most of the time.
Some of the words help the reader use the fives senses.
Words are vague or do not use the five senses to describe.
The word choice feels random and does not describe.
The writing is smooth and natural. The sentences are easy to read and understand.
Most sentences are smooth and sound natural.
Some sentences are smooth and sound natural.
Some of the writing is difficult to understand.
A few sentences are confusing. The meaning is not clear.
Many sentences are choppy or too long. The piece is difficult to read.
The writer uses nouns and verbs correctly.
The writing contains minimal errors with nouns and verbs.
A few errors with nouns and verbs can be easily corrected.
Errors with nouns and verbs confuse the reader.
Many errors with nouns and verbs stop the reader from understanding.
Serious, frequent errors make the writing very hard to understand.
